entries.title: Chile Wildfires Leave 13 Dead
entries.description: More than 150 fires burning in the country have also destroyed thousands of acres of forest, as the country faces a scorching heat wave.

entries.title: Russia Pushes to Take Ukrainian Town Near a Vital Supply Line
entries.description: Ukraine has used the strategic town of Vuhledar to launch attacks disrupting transit on a critical rail link between the war’s southern and eastern fronts.

entries.title: Hopes for Peace in South Sudan Are Pinned on a Papal Visit
entries.description: Pope Francis ended his trip to Africa on Saturday by meeting with displaced people and urging his clergy not to “remain neutral before the pain caused by acts of injustice and violence.”

entries.title: U.S. Presses Turkey and U.A.E. to Weed Out Illicit Trade With Russia
entries.description: American officials worry that commercial activities in Turkey and the United Arab Emirates could be fueling Russia’s war machine and have threatened to punish those involved.

entries.title: Russia Pushes to Take Ukrainian Town Near a Vital Supply Line
entries.description: The town of Vuhledar is just a few miles from a critical rail link. Its capture would enable Moscow to more easily transfer troops between the war’s southern and eastern fronts.

entries.title: Traveling and Eating Well
entries.description: When you travel, is tracking down a fantastic meal just as important as seeing the sights? I have tips to help.

entries.title: Some Homeless Encampments Can Stay, but the Underlying Issues Remain
entries.description: Three court decisions have now ruled that the shelter system does not meet the needs of homeless people.

entries.title: The Pentagon Saw a Warship Boondoggle. Congress Saw Jobs.
entries.description: After years of crippling problems and a changing mission, the Navy pushed to retire nine of its newest ships. Then the lobbying started.

entries.title: When It Comes to Building Its Own Defense, Europe Has Blinked
entries.description: Despite expectations that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine would force Europe to bolster its military strength, it has instead reinforced dependency on U.S. leadership, intelligence and might.

entries.title: What’s the Correct Color of Bees? In Austria, It’s a Toxic Topic.
entries.description: In the Austrian state of Carinthia, where the law favors light-colored local bees, those honey producers judged “too dark” risk eradication.

entries.title: Before Balloon Sighting, Classified Report Highlighted Foreign Surveillance Tech
entries.description: Before a Chinese spy balloon was discovered in the United States, American officials said a rival power may have used advanced technology to surveil U.S. military sites.

entries.title: Ties to Kabul Bombing Put ISIS Leader in Somalia in U.S. Cross Hairs
entries.description: Bilal al-Sudani’s financing of the ISIS branch in Afghanistan that killed 13 U.S. troops in 2021 elevated him on U.S. kill-or-capture lists.

entries.title: In London’s Poor‌ ‌Areas, Budget Cuts‌ and Youth Violence Collide
entries.description: Poor neighborhoods that have been hit hardest by austerity have also seen violence among young people surge or remain stubbornly high. Residents say that’s no coincidence.

entries.title: Balloon Incident Highlights Fragile State of U.S.-China Relationship
entries.description: Recent efforts by Beijing to mend ties with Washington were showing progress, but the balloon’s appearance over the United States illustrates lingering mistrust and growing tensions.

entries.title: Brazil Says It’s Started Sinking an Old Warship, Hazardous Material and All
entries.description: The navy said it had begun an operation to send the aircraft carrier São Paulo to the bottom.

entries.title: E.U. Vows More Help for Ukraine but Tamps Down Membership Talk
entries.description: European Union leaders met in Kyiv with President Volodymyr Zelensky, who said Ukraine would not give up on Bakhmut, the eastern city caught in a fierce battle with Russian forces.
